titleStmt.title: [A Man Steals Sweet Nuts from His Friend]

sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Colin M. (1959): Legends of the BaMbuti. In: The Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland 89(1), 45-60. Quot. p. 51.

projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from a narrator who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark up passages in quotation marks as, for example, q, quote, said, cit, or soCalled.

body.p: Two men went to their camp. While they were walking through the forest they came across a tree called pusia, which bears delicious nuts. One of the men gathered nuts from this tree, but the other gathered from another tree, whose nuts were very bitter. When they reached their camp they roasted their nuts over the fire. The man with the bitter nuts offered them to his friend. His friend tasted them and said "Oh! These are terrible, I can't eat them." And the two of them shared the sweet nuts. Later on the man with the bitter nuts went back to the tree and stole the rest of the sweet nuts and roasted them over the fire. When they were ready he offered them to his friend. His friend tasted them and said, "These are sweet, they must be my nuts. You have stolen my nuts." "I wouldn't steal your nuts!" "Well, tomorrow I'll go and see." At first light the man who had found the sweet nuts went to his tree, and saw that all the nuts were gone. Here turned to the camp and told his friend what he had found. "You see, you did steal all my nuts. You can stay here no longer."

So the man who stole the nuts left the camp and went through the forest until he came to a konga bird. When he saw the konga bird he explained what had happened and said, "Please, don't kill me." The konga bird said, "All right, you can stay here and look after us." In the mean-time the other pygmy, his nuts all eaten, decided to follow his friend. When he finally arrived his friend said to the konga bird, "There is my brother whose sweet nuts I stole. You can kill him if you like." So together they killed the pygmy who had allowed himself to be tricked. Basi ['That is all'].
